remixlab.dandelion.core

Class GrabberFrame

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.dandelion.geom.Frame
      • remixlab.dandelion.core.GrabberFrame
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Grabber, Trackable, Copyable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    GenericFrame, ModelFrame

    public class GrabberFrame
extends Frame
implements Grabber, Trackable
    A Frame implementing the Grabber interface, which converts user gestures into translation, rotation and scaling Frame updates (see translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity() and scalingSensitivity()). A grabber-frame may thus be attached to some of your scene objects to control their motion using an Agent, such as the GrabberScene.motionAgent() and the GrabberScene.keyboardAgent() (see GrabberFrame(GrabberScene) and all the constructors that take an scene parameter). To attach a grabber-frame to MyObject use code like this: 
     
 public class MyObject {
   public GrabberFrame gFrame;
   public void draw() {
     gFrame.scene().pushModelView();
     gFrame.applyWorldTransformation();
     drawMyObject();
     gFrame.scene().popModelView();
   }
 }
    See applyTransformation(), applyTransformation(), scene(), GrabberScene.pushModelView() and GrabberScene.popModelView()

    A grabber-frame may also be attached to an Eye, such as the GrabberScene.eyeFrame() which is attached to the GrabberScene.eye() (see isEyeFrame()). Some user gestures are then interpreted in a negated way, respect to eye detached frames. For instance, with a move-to-the-right user gesture the GrabberScene.eyeFrame() has to go to the left, so that the scene seems to move to the right. A grabber-frame can be attached to an eye only at construction times (see GrabberFrame(Eye) and all the constructors that take an eye parameter). An eye may have more than one grabber-frame attached to it. To set one of them as the Eye.frame(), call Eye.setFrame(GrabberFrame). Note that a grabber-frame may be detached from the eye at any time, see detach().

    This class provides several gesture-to-motion converting methods, such as: gestureArcball(MotionEvent), gestureMoveForward(DOF2Event, boolean), gestureTranslateX(KeyboardEvent, boolean), etc. To use them, derive from this class and override the version of performInteraction with the (bogus-event) parameter type you want to customize (see performInteraction(MotionEvent), performInteraction(KeyboardEvent), etc.). For example, with the following code: 

     
 protected void performInteraction(DOF2Event event) {
   if(event.id() == LEFT)
     gestureArcball(event);
   if(event.id() == RIGHT)
     gestureTranslateXY(event);
 }
    your custom grabber-frame will then accordingly react to the LEFT and RIGHT mouse buttons, provided it's added to the mouse-agent first (see Agent.addGrabber(Grabber).

    Picking a grabber-frame is simply done by checking if the pointer is within a circled area around the frame center() screen projection (see checkIfGrabsInput(float, float), setGrabsInputThreshold(float, boolean) and adaptiveGrabsInputThreshold()).

    A grabber-frame is loosely-coupled with the scene object used to instantiate it, i.e., the transformation it represents may be applied to a different scene. See applyTransformation() and applyTransformation(GrabberScene).

    Two grabber-frames can be synced together (sync(GrabberFrame, GrabberFrame)), meaning that they will share their global parameters (position, orientation and magnitude) taken the one that has been most recently updated. Syncing can be useful to share frames among different off-screen scenes (see ProScene's CameraCrane and the AuxiliarViewer examples).

    Finally, a grabber-frame can be followed by an Eye, defining a 'third-person' eye mode, see Trackable documentation. See also setTrackingEyeDistance(float), setTrackingEyeAzimuth(float) and setTrackingEyeInclination(float).

      • GrabberFrame

        public GrabberFrame(GrabberScene scn,
                    Frame referenceFrame,
                    Vec p,
                    Rotation r,
                    float s)
        Creates a scene grabber-frame with referenceFrame as Frame.referenceFrame(), and p, r and s as the frame Frame.translation(), Frame.rotation() and Frame.scaling(), respectively.

        The GrabberScene.inputHandler() will attempt to add the grabber-frame to all its InputHandler.agents(), such as the GrabberScene.motionAgent() and the GrabberScene.keyboardAgent().

        The grabber-frame sensitivities are set to their default values, see spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity(), keyboardSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), translationSensitivity() and scalingSensitivity().

        After object creation a call to isEyeFrame() will return false.

      • GrabberFrame

        public GrabberFrame(Eye eye,
                    Frame referenceFrame,
                    Vec p,
                    Rotation r,
                    float s)
        Creates an eye grabber-frame with referenceFrame as Frame.referenceFrame(), and p, r and s as the frame Frame.translation(), Frame.rotation() and Frame.scaling(), respectively.

        The grabber-frame isn't added to any of the GrabberScene.inputHandler() InputHandler.agents(). A call to GrabberScene.setEye(Eye) will do it.

        The grabber-frame sensitivities are set to their default values, see spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity(), keyboardSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), translationSensitivity() and scalingSensitivity().

        After object creation a call to isEyeFrame() will return true.

      • equals

      • detach

        public GrabberFrame detach()
        Description copied from class: Frame
        Returns a copy of this frame preserving its Frame.position(), Frame.orientation() and Frame.magnitude(), but discarding its Frame.referenceFrame() and Frame.children().
        Overrides:

      • scene

        public GrabberScene scene()
        Returns the scene this object belongs to.

        Note that if this isEyeFrame() then returns eye().scene().

        See Also:
        eye(), Eye.scene()

      • eye

        public Eye eye()
        Returns the eye object this grabber-frame is attached to. May be null if the grabber-frame is not attach to an eye.
        See Also:
        isEyeFrame()

      • isEyeFrame

        public boolean isEyeFrame()
        Returns true if the grabber-frame is attached to an eye, and false otherwise. Grabber-frames can only be attached to an eye at construction times. Refer to the grabber-frame constructors that take an eye parameter.
        See Also:
        eye()

        Very efficient prefer always this than

        See Also:

      • lastUpdate

        Returns:
        the last frame the Frame was updated.

      • sync

        public void sync(GrabberFrame otherFrame)
        Same as sync(this, otherFrame).
        See Also:
        sync(GrabberFrame, GrabberFrame)

      • sync

        public static void sync(GrabberFrame f1,
                        GrabberFrame f2)
        If f1 has been more recently updated than f2, calls f2.fromFrame(f1), otherwise calls f1.fromFrame(f2).

        This method syncs only the global parameters (Frame.position(), Frame.orientation() and Frame.magnitude()) among the two frames. The Frame.referenceFrame() and Frame.constraint() (if any) of each frame are kept separately.

        See Also:
        Frame.fromFrame(Frame)

      • damping

        public float damping()
        Defines the spinning deceleration.

        Default value is 0.5. Use setDamping(float) to tune this value. A higher value will make damping more difficult (a value of 1.0 forbids damping).

      • setDamping

        public void setDamping(float f)
        Defines the damping(). Values must be in the range [0..1].

      • setRotationSensitivity

        public final void setRotationSensitivity(float sensitivity)
        Defines the rotationSensitivity().

      • setScalingSensitivity

        public final void setScalingSensitivity(float sensitivity)
        Defines the scalingSensitivity().

      • setTranslationSensitivity

        public final void setTranslationSensitivity(float sensitivity)
        Defines the translationSensitivity().

      • setSpinningSensitivity

        public final void setSpinningSensitivity(float sensitivity)
        Defines the spinningSensitivity().

      • setWheelSensitivity

        public final void setWheelSensitivity(float sensitivity)
        Defines the wheelSensitivity().

      • setKeyboardSensitivity

        public final void setKeyboardSensitivity(float sensitivity)
        Defines the keyboardSensitivity().

      • rotationSensitivity

        public final float rotationSensitivity()
        Returns the influence of a gesture displacement on the grabber-frame rotation.

        Default value is 1.0 (which matches an identical mouse displacement), a higher value will generate a larger rotation (and inversely for lower values). A 0.0 value will forbid rotation (see also Frame.constraint()).

        See Also:
        setRotationSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), keyboardSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

      • scalingSensitivity

        public final float scalingSensitivity()
        Returns the influence of a gesture displacement on the grabber-frame scaling.

        Default value is 1.0, a higher value will generate a larger scaling (and inversely for lower values). A 0.0 value will forbid scaling (see also Frame.constraint()).

        See Also:
        setScalingSensitivity(float), setRotationSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), keyboardSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

      • translationSensitivity

        public final float translationSensitivity()
        Returns the influence of a gesture displacement on the grabber-frame translation.

        Default value is 1.0 which in the case of a mouse interaction makes the grabber-frame precisely stays under the mouse cursor.

        With an identical gesture displacement, a higher value will generate a larger translation (and inversely for lower values). A 0.0 value will forbid translation (see also Frame.constraint()).

        See Also:
        setTranslationSensitivity(float), rotationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), keyboardSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

      • spinningSensitivity

        public final float spinningSensitivity()
        Returns the minimum gesture speed required to make the grabber-frame spin(). Spinning requires to set to damping() to 0.

        See spin(), spinningRotation() and startSpinning(MotionEvent, Rotation) for details.

        Gesture speed is expressed in pixels per milliseconds. Default value is 0.3 (300 pixels per second). Use setSpinningSensitivity(float) to tune this value. A higher value will make spinning more difficult (a value of 100.0 forbids spinning in practice).

        See Also:
        setSpinningSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), keyboardSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity(), setDamping(float)

      • wheelSensitivity

        public float wheelSensitivity()
        Returns the wheel sensitivity.

        Default value is 5.0. A higher value will make the wheel action more efficient (usually meaning faster motion). Use a negative value to invert the operation direction.

        See Also:
        setWheelSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), keyboardSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity()

      • keyboardSensitivity

        public float keyboardSensitivity()
        Returns the keyboard sensitivity.

        Default value is 10. A higher value will make the keyboard more efficient (usually meaning faster motion).

        See Also:
        setKeyboardSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), scalingSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity(), setDamping(float)

      • isSpinning

        public final boolean isSpinning()
        Returns true when the grabber-frame is spinning.

        During spinning, spin() rotates the grabber-frame by its spinningRotation() at a frequency defined when the grabber-frame startSpinning(MotionEvent, Rotation).

        Use startSpinning(MotionEvent, Rotation) and stopSpinning() to change this state. Default value is false.

        See Also:
        isFlying()

      • spinningRotation

        public final Rotation spinningRotation()
        Returns the incremental rotation that is applied by spin() to the grabber-frame orientation when it isSpinning().

        Default value is a null rotation. Use setSpinningRotation(Rotation) to change this value.

        The spinningRotation() axis is defined in the grabber-frame coordinate system. You can use Frame.transformOfFrom(Vec, Frame) to convert this axis from another Frame coordinate system.

        Attention: Spinning may be decelerated according to damping() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        flyDirection()

      • setSpinningRotation

        public final void setSpinningRotation(Rotation spinningRotation)
        Defines the spinningRotation(). Its axis is defined in the grabber-frame coordinate system.
        See Also:
        setFlyDirection(Vec)

      • stopSpinning

        public final void stopSpinning()
        Stops the spinning motion started using startSpinning(MotionEvent, Rotation). isSpinning() will return false after this call.

        Attention: This method may be called by spin(), since spinning may be decelerated according to damping() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        damping()

      • startSpinning

        public void startSpinning(Rotation rt,
                          float speed,
                          long delay)
        Starts the spinning of the grabber-frame.

        This method starts a timer that will call spin() every updateInterval milliseconds. The grabber-frame isSpinning() until you call stopSpinning().

        Attention: Spinning may be decelerated according to damping() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        damping(), startFlying(Vec, float)

      • deformedBallRotation

        public Rotation deformedBallRotation(DOF2Event event,
                                     Vec center)
        Returns a Rotation computed according to the mouse motion. Mouse positions are projected on a deformed ball, centered on (center.x(), center.y()).

      • align

        public void align()
        Wrapper method for Frame.alignWithFrame(Frame, boolean, float) that discriminates between eye and non-eye frames.

      • center

        public void center()
        Centers the grabber-frame into the scene.

        See Also:
        screenToEye(Vec), eyeToReferenceFrame(Vec)

                               float y,
                               float z)
        Same as return eyeToReferenceFrame(new Vec(x, y, z)).
        See Also:
        eyeToReferenceFrame(Vec)

      • eyeToReferenceFrame

        public Vec eyeToReferenceFrame(Vec trns)
        Converts the vector from eye coordinates to Frame.referenceFrame() coordinates.

        It's worth noting that all gesture to grabber-frame motion converting methods, are implemented from just screenToEye(Vec), eyeToReferenceFrame(Vec) and screenToQuat(float, float, float).

        See Also:
        screenToEye(Vec), screenToQuat(float, float, float)

      • screenToEye

        public Vec screenToEye(float x,
                       float y,
                       float z)
        Same as return screenToEye(new Vec(x, y, z)).
        See Also:
        screenToEye(Vec)

      • screenToEye

        public Vec screenToEye(Vec trns)
        Converts the vector from screen (device) coordinates into eye coordinates.

        It's worth noting that all gesture to grabber-frame motion converting methods, are implemented from just screenToEye(Vec), eyeToReferenceFrame(Vec) and screenToQuat(float, float, float).

        See Also:
        eyeToReferenceFrame(Vec), screenToQuat(float, float, float)

      • screenToQuat

        public Quat screenToQuat(Vec angles)
        Same as return screenToQuat(angles.vec[0], angles.vec[1], angles.vec[2]).
        See Also:
        screenToQuat(float, float, float)

      • screenToQuat

        public Quat screenToQuat(float roll,
                         float pitch,
                         float yaw)
        Reduces the screen (device) Extrinsic rotation into a Quat.

        It's worth noting that all gesture to grabber-frame motion converting methods, are implemented from just screenToEye(Vec), eyeToReferenceFrame(Vec) and screenToQuat(float, float, float).

        Parameters:
        roll - Rotation angle in radians around the screen x-Axis
        pitch - Rotation angle in radians around the screen y-Axis
        yaw - Rotation angle in radians around the screen z-Axis
        See Also:
        Quat.fromEulerAngles(float, float, float)

      • rotateAroundFrame

        public void rotateAroundFrame(float roll,
                              float pitch,
                              float yaw,
                              Frame frame)
        Overrides:
        rotateAroundFrame in class Frame

      • sceneUpVector

        public Vec sceneUpVector()
        Returns the up vector used in gestureMoveForward(MotionEvent) in which horizontal displacements of the motion device (e.g., mouse) rotate grabber-frame around this vector. Vertical displacements rotate always around the grabber-frame X axis.

        This value is also used within gestureRotateCAD(MotionEvent) to define the up vector (and incidentally the 'horizon' plane) around which the grabber-frame will rotate.

        Default value is (0,1,0), but it is updated by the Eye when set as its Eye.frame(). Eye.setOrientation(Rotation) and Eye.setUpVector(Vec) modify this value and should be used instead.

      • setSceneUpVector

        public void setSceneUpVector(Vec up)
        Sets the sceneUpVector(), defined in the world coordinate system.

        Default value is (0,1,0), but it is updated by the Eye when set as its Eye.frame(). Use Eye.setUpVector(Vec) instead in that case.

      • updateSceneUpVector

        public final void updateSceneUpVector()
        This method will be called by the Eye when its orientation is changed, so that the sceneUpVector() is changed accordingly. You should not need to call this method.

      • isFlying

        public final boolean isFlying()
        Returns true when the grabber-frame is tossing.

        During tossing, damping() translates the grabber-frame by its flyDirection() at a frequency defined when the grabber-frame startFlying(MotionEvent, Vec).

        Use startFlying(MotionEvent, Vec) and stopFlying() to change this state. Default value is false. isSpinning()

      • stopFlying

        public final void stopFlying()
        Stops the tossing motion started using startFlying(MotionEvent, Vec). isFlying() will return false after this call.

        Attention: This method may be called by damping(), since tossing may be decelerated according to damping() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        damping(), spin()

      • flyDirection

        public final Vec flyDirection()
        Returns the incremental translation that is applied by damping() to the grabber-frame position when it isFlying().

        Default value is no translation. Use setFlyDirection(Vec) to change this value.

        Attention: Tossing may be decelerated according to damping() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        spinningRotation()

      • setFlyDirection

        public final void setFlyDirection(Vec dir)
        Defines the flyDirection() in the reference frame coordinate system.
        See Also:
        setSpinningRotation(Rotation)

      • startFlying

        public void startFlying(Vec direction,
                        float speed)
        Starts the tossing of the grabber-frame.

        This method starts a timer that will call damping() every FLY_UPDATE_PERDIOD milliseconds. The grabber-frame isFlying() until you call stopFlying().

        Attention: Tossing may be decelerated according to damping() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        damping(), spin(), startFlying(MotionEvent, Vec), startSpinning(Rotation, float, long)

      • flySpeed

        public float flySpeed()
        Returns the fly speed, expressed in virtual scene units.

        It corresponds to the incremental displacement that is periodically applied to the grabber-frame by gestureMoveForward(MotionEvent, boolean).

        Attention: When the grabber-frame is set as the Eye.frame() or when it is set as the GrabberScene.avatar() (which indeed is an instance of the InteractiveAvatarFrame class), this value is set according to the GrabberScene.radius() by GrabberScene.setRadius(float).

      • setFlySpeed

        public void setFlySpeed(float speed)
        Sets the flySpeed(), defined in virtual scene units.

        Default value is 0.0, but it is modified according to the GrabberScene.radius() when the grabber-frame is set as the Eye.frame() (which indeed is an instance of the grabber-frame class) or when the grabber-frame is set as the GrabberScene.avatar() (which indeed is an instance of the InteractiveAvatarFrame class).

      • grabsInputThreshold

        public float grabsInputThreshold()
        Returns the grabs input threshold which is used by the interactive frame to checkIfGrabsInput(BogusEvent).
        See Also:
        setGrabsInputThreshold(float)

      • adaptiveGrabsInputThreshold

        public boolean adaptiveGrabsInputThreshold()
        Returns true if the checkIfGrabsInput(BogusEvent) test is adaptive and false otherwise.
        See Also:
        setGrabsInputThreshold(float, boolean)

      • setGrabsInputThreshold

        public void setGrabsInputThreshold(float threshold)
        Convenience function that simply calls setGrabsInputThreshold(threshold, false).
        See Also:
        setGrabsInputThreshold(float, boolean)

      • setGrabsInputThreshold

        public void setGrabsInputThreshold(float threshold,
                                   boolean adaptive)
        Sets the length of the hint that defined the checkIfGrabsInput(BogusEvent) condition used for frame picking.

        If adaptive is false, the threshold is expressed in pixels and directly defines the fixed length of the GrabberScene.drawShooterTarget(Vec, float), centered at the projection of the frame origin onto the screen.

        If adaptive is true, the threshold is expressed in object space (world units) and defines the edge length of a squared bounding box that leads to an adaptive length of the GrabberScene.drawShooterTarget(Vec, float), centered at the projection of the frame origin onto the screen. Use this version only if you have a good idea of the bounding box size of the object you are attaching to the frame.

        Default behavior is to set the grabsInputThreshold() to 20 pixels length (in a non-adaptive manner).

        Negative threshold values are silently ignored.

        See Also:
        grabsInputThreshold(), checkIfGrabsInput(BogusEvent)

      • grabsInput

        public boolean grabsInput(Agent agent)
        Check if this object is the Agent.inputGrabber(). Returns true if this object grabs the agent and false otherwise.

      • grabsInput

        public boolean grabsInput()
        Checks if the frame grabs input from any agent registered at the scene input handler.

        Same as return scene().avatar() == this.
